Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Distant Dusty Massively Star-forming Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the cosmic history of star formation is one of the fundamental goals in contemporary astronomy. Much of the light produced by star formation over cosmic time is obscured by dust and reradiated at far-infrared (FIR) wavelengths. For redshifts > 1, this light may be detected as submillimeter (submm) galaxies. Unfortunately, current studies of dust-obscured, star-forming galaxies at these distances are limited by confusion and blending, which prevents us from studying the dominant populations that produce the FIR extragalactic background light. In order to address this concern, the PIs will use the new SCUBA-2 submm camera on the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope at 450 microns (and simultaneously at 850 microns) to obtain high-resolution observations of submm galaxies.

This work will signiﬁcantly expand our understanding of the submm universe and the history of dusty star formation. The research team will also work with graduate students to develop a science activity for high school students that will teach them about dust in galaxies. Finally, the PIs will train graduate students in submm and radio astronomy, the facilities for which the U.S. has made significant investments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mapping the star formation history of the universe is one of the fundamental goals of astronomy and key to understanding how the present-day population of galaxies came into being. Unfortunately, obscuration by dust in galaxies makes optical surveys of star formation highly incomplete, especially for the most massive galaxies. In this program, we used the new SCUBA-2 submillimeter camera on the 15m James Clerk Maxwell Telescope (JCMT) on Mauna Kea to map galaxies whose star formation is obscured by dust. At the longer wavelengths (850 micron), we needed to augment the low-resolution observations of the single-dish JCMT with interferometric observations from the Submillimeter Array on Mauna Kea and the ALMA array in Chile in order to obtain precise positions for the galaxies. At the shorter wavelengths (450 micron), we obtained reasonable resolution with the JCMT for a smaller number of galaxies. We enhanced the sensitivity of some of our observations by observing massive galaxy cluster fields, where there is substantial magnification of background galaxies due to gravitational lensing.

 

With the precise submillimeter positions, we were able to compare directly with optical and radio data. We found that nearly all of the star formation taking place in the most powerfully star-forming galaxies in the universe is obscured by dust. Only for galaxies with star formation rates below about 500 solar masses per year did we begin to see major overlap with optically selected populations. Strikingly, galaxies with higher star formation rates than this contain about 30% of the total star formation out to very early times in the history of the universe. We confirmed for the first time that even at lower star formation rates, there are galaxies that are very faint in the optical but strong in the submillimeter. These galaxies suggest that we may be missing yet more dust-obscured star formation from our census.

 

We trained graduate and undergraduate students in submillimeter and optical astronomy, preparing them for STEM careers. We also developed a number of projects that allow graduate students and the general public to carry out submillimeter research on their own and experience writing a paper based on cutting-edge data.
